elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention in the past decade owing to their unprecedented internal surface areas, tunable topologies, designable surfaces, and various potential applications. One bottleneck in the field regarding MOF synthesis is controlling the metal-containing secondary building unit (SBU) incorporated into the structure. In this work we report the synthesis and characterization of five trimeric [M3(μ3-O)­(CH3CO2)6] x clusters (where M = Fe3+, Cr3+, Fe3+/Cr3+, Fe3+/Co2+, or Fe3+/Ni2+ and x = +1 or 0). The monocarboxylate capping ligand, acetate in this case, readily undergoes exchange with several difunctional counterparts, including 1,4-benzene­dicarboxylic acid (H2-BDC) and biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (H2-BPDC), for the formation of an isostructural series of MOFs, several of which are newly reported (for M = Fe3+/Cr3+, Fe3+/Co2+, and Fe3+/Ni2+) and show excellent CO2 adsorption properties. In this report, a host of techniques including NMR, ICP, and ESI-MS are used to probe the ligand exchange process and composition of the SBUs, and XAS is used to monitor the Fe3+ and Cr3+ environment throughout the reactions, giving strong evidence that the clusters stay intact throughout the MOF synthesis. This work reveals that predefined SBUs is an effective means to create metal-substituted analogues of known frameworks. Further, CO adsorption and in situ IR are used to probe accessibility of the metals after solvent removal. We show for the first time that the incorporation of the neutral clusters, containing weaker Lewis acids like Ni2+ and Co2+, can promote the formation of open metal sites in the MOF frameworks, structural features known to enhance the binding energy of small guest molecules like CO2.

elements.content: Since the discovery of their permanent porosity almost two decades ago, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have remained at the forefront of materials research. MOFs, constructed by metal ions or metal ion clusters that are interlinked by organic ligands, offer unprecedented internal surface areas that allow the adsorption of substantial amounts of guest species. Further, the molecular nature of the organic ligands within the hybrid organic/inorganic frameworks induces structural versatility, allows the introduction of multifunctional properties, and permits a modular approach to their design. In these ways MOFs are unique relative to their all-inorganic counterparts, offering unmatched opportunities to achieve optimal efficiencies in a wide range of applications related to gas storage and separation, catalysis, sensing, and drug delivery. All of these attributes have created a scientific surge toward the discovery of new MOF materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since the discovery of their permanent porosity almost two decades ago, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have remained at the forefront of materials research. MOFs, constructed by metal ions or metal ion clusters that are interlinked by organic ligands, offer unprecedented internal surface areas that allow the adsorption of substantial amounts of guest species. Further, the molecular nature of the organic ligands within the hybrid organic/inorganic frameworks induces structural versatility, allows the introduction of multifunctional properties, and permits a modular approach to their design. In these ways MOFs are unique relative to their all-inorganic counterparts, offering unmatched opportunities to achieve optimal efficiencies in a wide range of applications related to gas storage and separation, catalysis, sensing, and drug delivery. All of these attributes have created a scientific surge toward the discovery of new MOF materials.

elements.content: With the vast number of potential building block combinations, one could envisage the synthesis of millions of new materials. However, synthesizing the nearly infinite number of possible frameworks is a daunting task even for the most skilled chemist. Up to the present, synthetic conditions for new frameworks are discovered through empirical, exploratory methods that can sometimes require hundreds or even thousands of chemical reactions to isolate a single new porous hybrid framework. This difficulty has led to a bottleneck in the field, as materials synthesis cannot keep pace with developing computational efforts aimed at structure and property prediction. These limitations stem from our inability to dictate how the metal ions and/or secondary building units behave in solution. Knowledge of how to control the metal-containing building blocks incorporated into these unique frameworks will facilitate the synthesis of new classes of hybrid materials with highly desirable catalytic, gas storage/separation, and optical properties. It will allow us the means to create more chemically complex materials such as mixed-metal MOFs and those that contain multiple SBUs of different shape and connectivity to achieve multifunctional properties. In addition, using predefined building blocks significantly reduces the structural degrees of freedom allowing much easier computational prediction of potential framework structures and hence their corresponding properties.

elements.content: In this work (), we develop a rational approach to the design and assembly of MOFs using predefined molecular-like, metal-oxide building blocks that are “capped” with labile ligands (A). First, five trimeric [M3(μ3-O)­(CH3CO2)6] x clusters (where M = Fe3+, Cr3+, Fe3+/Cr3+, Fe3+/Co2+, or Fe3+/Ni2+ and x = +1 or 0) were synthesized. The capping acetate ligands were subsequently exchanged with their multifunctional counterparts, including 1,4-benzene­dicarboxylic acid (H2-BDC) and biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (H2-BPDC) for the formation of an isoreticular series of MOFs (B,C). Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) coupled with a host of spectroscopic techniques (infrared spectroscopy, IR; nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, NMR; X-ray absorption spectroscopy, XAS) is used to show stability of SBUs upon dissolution and monitor the SBUs state during the ligand exchange process. While there are a few studies that show the use of predefined clusters as building blocks for MOF synthesis, this is the first study, to the best of our knowledge, showing a detailed analysis of SBUs in solution combined with subsequent MOF formation.

elements.content: To begin the work, a series of metal clusters containing the triangular M3(μ3-O) core capped with six acetate anions were synthesized. From this effort, five clusters with varying composition were isolated including [M3O­(CH3CO2)6(H2O)3]+, where M­(III)3O = Fe3O, Cr3O, or Fe2CrO and [Fe2MO­(CH3CO2)6(H2O)3] where Fe­(III)2M­(II)O = Fe2CoO or Fe2NiO. The single crystal structures of the Cr3O cluster, obtained from diffraction experiments (CCDC deposition 1539824), and the previously reported structure of Fe3O provide quick evidence for the correct phase formation via powder X-ray diffraction followed by subsequent Le Bail fitting (Figures S1–S3). The crystal structures of the mixed metal clusters, Fe2CrO, Fe2CoO, and Fe2NiO, which are to date unreported, are expected to be different from Fe3O and Cr3O as indicated by the pxrd patterns (Figure S1). Given our inability to grow single crystals of these clusters, we have relied on a number of other characterization techniques to indicate their purity and composition. Characterization including MS, EDX, ICP, and IR was deemed necessary to prove the presence and purity of the three mixed metal clusters. First, EDX and ICP-OES gave evidence of the correct Fe:M ratio of ∼2:1 for the three Fe2MO samples both on the surface of individual particles and in the bulk powder phase, respectively (Figure S4). Further, elemental mapping, carried out on the surface of the polycrystalline powders showed a homogeneous distribution of the Fe and M atoms (Figure S4). ESI-MS was then used to add further proof that the clusters formed in the crystalline powder samples consist only of the targeted composition. For this, the powders were dissolved in 1 mL of MeOH/H2O and rediluted in MeOH for a final concentration of 10 μM, and then ESI-MS was used to determine the mass of the ionized species present in the aerosol. The observed peaks in the MS spectra include m/z values of 562.87 and 563.87 for [Fe2NiO­(CH3CO2)6]­Na+ and [Fe2CoO­(CH3CO2)6]­Na+, respectively, and m/z values of 533.88 and 525.9 for [Fe2CrO­(CH3CO2)6]+ and [Cr3O­(CH3CO2)6]+, respectively (Figure S5). It should be noted that for all mixed metal clusters no evidence of the Fe3O or Cr3O clusters was observed in ESI-MS, indicating that the target compositions are indeed achieved. Last, IR-ATR data (Figure S6) proved the successful synthesis of these clusters in the solid state. The intense absorption bands at around 1580 and 1420 cm–1 are assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric stretches of the −COO– groups of the acetate anion, respectively. Absorption in the range of 400–800 cm–1 is further used for the identification of the metal-μ3-oxo bands of the M3(μ3-O) core. In the IR spectrum of the Fe2CoO, Fe2NiO, and Fe2CrO clusters, the characteristic stretching vibration observed for the Fe3(μ3-O) core (at ∼600 cm–1) disappears, and two new bands appear. This is due to a reduction in the site geometry from D 3h to C 2v upon metal substitution, which lifts the degeneracy of the asymmetric metal-μ3-oxo stretching vibrations. More detailed analysis is discussed in the Supporting Information (Figure S6).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of Trimeric Clusters with Varying Metals

To begin the work, a series of metal clusters containing the triangular M3(μ3-O) core capped with six acetate anions were synthesized. From this effort, five clusters with varying composition were isolated including [M3O(CH3CO2)6(H2O)3]+, where M(III)3O = Fe3O, Cr3O, or Fe2CrO and [Fe2MO(CH3CO2)6(H2O)3] where Fe(III)2M(II)O = Fe2CoO or Fe2NiO. The single crystal structures of the Cr3O cluster, obtained from diffraction experiments (CCDC deposition 1539824), and the previously reported structure of Fe3O provide quick evidence for the correct phase formation via powder X-ray diffraction followed by subsequent Le Bail fitting (Figures S1-S3). The crystal structures of the mixed metal clusters, Fe2CrO, Fe2CoO, and Fe2NiO, which are to date unreported, are expected to be different from Fe3O and Cr3O as indicated by the pxrd patterns (Figure S1). Given our inability to grow single crystals of these clusters, we have relied on a number of other characterization techniques to indicate their purity and composition. Characterization including MS, EDX, ICP, and IR was deemed necessary to prove the presence and purity of the three mixed metal clusters. First, EDX and ICP-OES gave evidence of the correct Fe:M ratio of ~2:1 for the three Fe2MO samples both on the surface of individual particles and in the bulk powder phase, respectively (Figure S4). Further, elemental mapping, carried out on the surface of the polycrystalline powders showed a homogeneous distribution of the Fe and M atoms (Figure S4). ESI-MS was then used to add further proof that the clusters formed in the crystalline powder samples consist only of the targeted composition. For this, the powders were dissolved in 1 mL of MeOH/H2O and rediluted in MeOH for a final concentration of 10 μM, and then ESI-MS was used to determine the mass of the ionized species present in the aerosol. The observed peaks in the MS spectra include m/z values of 562.87 and 563.87 for [Fe2NiO(CH3CO2)6]Na+ and [Fe2CoO(CH3CO2)6]Na+, respectively, and m/z values of 533.88 and 525.9 for [Fe2CrO(CH3CO2)6]+ and [Cr3O(CH3CO2)6]+, respectively (Figure S5). It should be noted that for all mixed metal clusters no evidence of the Fe3O or Cr3O clusters was observed in ESI-MS, indicating that the target compositions are indeed achieved. Last, IR-ATR data (Figure S6) proved the successful synthesis of these clusters in the solid state. The intense absorption bands at around 1580 and 1420 cm-1 are assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric stretches of the -COO- groups of the acetate anion, respectively. Absorption in the range of 400-800 cm-1 is further used for the identification of the metal-μ3-oxo bands of the M3(μ3-O) core. In the IR spectrum of the Fe2CoO, Fe2NiO, and Fe2CrO clusters, the characteristic stretching vibration observed for the Fe3(μ3-O) core (at ~600 cm-1) disappears, and two new bands appear. This is due to a reduction in the site geometry from D 3h  to C 2v  upon metal substitution, which lifts the degeneracy of the asymmetric metal-μ3-oxo stretching vibrations. More detailed analysis is discussed in the Supporting Information (Figure S6).

elements.content: Once characterization of the targeted clusters was completed, efforts were made to isolate reaction conditions under which subsequent MOF crystallization could be achieved using several dicarboxylic acids that are common to MOF chemistry. In hopes that the predefined metal clusters could simply undergo ligand exchange reactions for the MOF formation, the Fe3O core was first mixed with biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (H2-BPDC). Several parameters were varied including the ratios of starting materials, solvents, amount and identity of modulators, and temperatures, all of which might influence the rate of the ligand exchange process and hence the prospect of MOF crystallization. Once the reaction conditions necessary for the crystallization of MOF Fe3O-BPDC (1) were isolated, the same conditions were applied to the four remaining clusters. A single crystal structure obtained from 1 (CCDC deposition 1539823) shows a similar structure to MIL-126 with the following composition: [Fe3O­(H2O)2(OH)­[(BPDC)3]·n(solvent). The simulated powder pattern from 1 closely matches MOFs obtained from the Fe2CoO (2), Fe2NiO (3), and Fe2CrO (4) core (), giving solid evidence of the formation of an isostructural series. Obviously these MOFs are highly crystalline and show all the characteristic peaks of the simulated data of 1. Le Bail fits of the powder X-ray diffraction data (Figure S7) were used to extract the unit cell parameters for each material refined in tetragonal space group (P43212) (Table S1), and to the best of our knowledge 2–4 are newly reported compositions. The Le Bail fits (Figure S7) for the as-prepared MOFs show excellent agreement with the expected space group and unit cell with all observed diffraction peaks allowed. The results indicate the BPDC containing MOFs are quite pure. TGA analysis, carried out under flowing air, reveals similarities in the thermal stability for all MOFs in this series despite the varying compositions, with decomposition temperatures approaching 340 °C (Figure S8). It should additionally be noted that efforts made to synthesize a MOF containing the Cr3(μ3-O) building block failed, and instead, the diffraction pattern shows broad diffuse scattering (Figure S9). While the gel material still shows permanent porosity (Figure S10), we were unable to isolate the reaction conditions to form an isostructural, crystalline material, 5. This issue is likely due to the Cr3+, which is kinetically inert relative to the other first row transition metals, making the ligand exchange process quite slow. It is thought that the synthesis of highly crystalline MOFs often requires a self-healing mechanism, with high ligand lability to achieve long-range crystalline order.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of MOFs with Varying Clusters and H2-BPDC

Once characterization of the targeted clusters was completed, efforts were made to isolate reaction conditions under which subsequent MOF crystallization could be achieved using several dicarboxylic acids that are common to MOF chemistry. In hopes that the predefined metal clusters could simply undergo ligand exchange reactions for the MOF formation, the Fe3O core was first mixed with biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (H2-BPDC). Several parameters were varied including the ratios of starting materials, solvents, amount and identity of modulators, and temperatures, all of which might influence the rate of the ligand exchange process and hence the prospect of MOF crystallization. Once the reaction conditions necessary for the crystallization of MOF Fe3O-BPDC (1) were isolated, the same conditions were applied to the four remaining clusters. A single crystal structure obtained from 1 (CCDC deposition 1539823) shows a similar structure to MIL-126 with the following composition: [Fe3O(H2O)2(OH)[(BPDC)3]⋅n(solvent). The simulated powder pattern from 1 closely matches MOFs obtained from the Fe2CoO (2), Fe2NiO (3), and Fe2CrO (4) core (), giving solid evidence of the formation of an isostructural series. Obviously these MOFs are highly crystalline and show all the characteristic peaks of the simulated data of 1. Le Bail fits of the powder X-ray diffraction data (Figure S7) were used to extract the unit cell parameters for each material refined in tetragonal space group (P43212) (Table S1), and to the best of our knowledge 2-4 are newly reported compositions. The Le Bail fits (Figure S7) for the as-prepared MOFs show excellent agreement with the expected space group and unit cell with all observed diffraction peaks allowed. The results indicate the BPDC containing MOFs are quite pure. TGA analysis, carried out under flowing air, reveals similarities in the thermal stability for all MOFs in this series despite the varying compositions, with decomposition temperatures approaching 340 °C (Figure S8). It should additionally be noted that efforts made to synthesize a MOF containing the Cr3(μ3-O) building block failed, and instead, the diffraction pattern shows broad diffuse scattering (Figure S9). While the gel material still shows permanent porosity (Figure S10), we were unable to isolate the reaction conditions to form an isostructural, crystalline material, 5. This issue is likely due to the Cr3+, which is kinetically inert relative to the other first row transition metals, making the ligand exchange process quite slow. It is thought that the synthesis of highly crystalline MOFs often requires a self-healing mechanism, with high ligand lability to achieve long-range crystalline order.

elements.content: Considering MOFs are prone to undergo metal exchange, various forms of characterization were employed to show that the cluster compositions inside MOFs 2–4 are indeed the same as the Fe2MO building blocks. First EDX analysis of 2–4 clearly indicated a Fe:M ratio of ∼2:1, and ICP-OES analysis of the digested bulk powder samples also confirmed the same results (Figure S11). Likewise, FT-IR spectra reveal metal-μ3-oxo stretches at positions similar to those of their corresponding building blocks (Figures S12 and S13).

Likewise, FT-IR spectra reveal metal-μ3-oxo stretches at positions similar to those of their corresponding building blocks (Figures S12 and S13).

elements.content: Nitrogen adsorption measurements of 1–4 show a typical type I isotherm indicative of microporosity (A). The BET surface areas of MOFs synthesized from Fe2NiO (4), Fe2CoO (3), or Fe2CrO (2) are 830, 1327, and 2000 m2/g, respectively. The Fe3O-BPDC analogue (1) has a surface area, 1690 m2/g, similarly reported for MOF-126 by Serre et al. The gelatinous phase containing the Cr3O cluster, 5, exhibits a BET surface area of 602 m2/g (Figure S10). While this surface area was obtained using normal activation procedures with heat and vacuum, it is expected that higher surface areas could be achieved with supercritical CO2 extraction. While it is not known why the surface areas of 2 and 3 are so much lower than 1 and 4, it could be related to crystalline defects induced by the mismatch in the ligand exchange rate of the M2+ and M3+ cations in 2 and 3, differences in nucleation and growth rates, or other issues regarding the framework charge. For 1 and 4, the clusters are charged, while those in 2 and 3 are neutral, which could lend to differences in charge balancing guests and solvent located in the channels.

elements.content: Given the considerable surface area of this isostructural series and the propensity of the M3(μ3-O) core to form open metal coordination sites (OMCs) upon activation, the CO2 adsorption properties of these MOFs were probed at 298 K. B and Figure S14 show the room-temperature excess adsorption isotherms for 1–5. Surprisingly, these MOFs showed moderate to excellent CO2 adsorption capacities. Especially 1, synthesized from Fe3O cluster, reached 4.04 mmol of CO2 per gram at atmospheric pressure. For 2, 3, 4, and 5, the capacities are 2.00, 1.78, 1.02 (B), and 1.01 mmol/g (Figure S14) at atmospheric pressure. Additionally, isosteric heats were extracted from the variable temperature CO2 adsorption isotherms ranging from 288 to 308 K. The CO2 adsorption isotherms collected at 288, 298, and 308 K were fitted with a dual-site Langmuir model (Table S2 and Figure S15), and then the Clausius–Clapeyron equation was subsequently used to extract the isosteric heats of CO2 adsorption, Q st. The Q st are plotted as a function of CO2 loading in Figure S16. At zero coverage the values are 20.5, 23.7, 27.4, and 20.8 kJ mol–1 for 1, 2, 3, and 4, respectively. It should be noted that despite their lower overall CO2 capacity and surface area, analogues that contain neutral clusters (Fe2CoO-BPDC (2) and Fe2NiO-BPDC (3)) have a higher Q st, with Ni2+ showing the highest of 27.4 kJ/mol. These significant differences in the corresponding isosteric heats likely imply that the identity of the metal significantly influences the strength of binding.

elements.content: Despite the similarities in the structures of the SBU, there are wide variations in the adsorption properties of the resulting MOFs. The significant differences in the CO2 adsorption behavior might be related to any one or combination of the following: the presence of OMCs that give rise to differences in binding energies, variations in the level of activation and/or accessibility of the OMCs, and the aforementioned defects. Given the higher Q st for 3 and 4, we decided to use in situ DRIFTs to probe the presence of OMCs, which are known to increase binding energy and the surface packing density of adsorbates, provide selectivity for the adsorption of CO2 over N2, and also, on a few occasions, provide a means to achieve charge transfer between the MOF and guest species. For this, MOFs 1–4 were activated at 150 °C and then dosed with CO (5–20 mbar), and in situ DRIFTs data were collected at 150 K. When compared with the stretching mode of free CO (2143 cm–1), 2 and 3 show significant blue-shifts approximately 20 cm–1 (2163 cm–1) and 30 cm–1 (2173 cm–1), respectively, indicating a strong interaction between the CO and the framework (, see detailed discussion in Figure S17). The observed stretching frequencies are consistent with those previously reported for Co2(dobdc) (2164 cm–1) and Ni2(dobdc) (2174 cm–1) with 20 mbar of CO, which are known to have OMCs. This result implies that Co2+ and Ni2+ sites of 2 and 3 are accessible post activation (see the Supporting Information for further details). When the same experiment is performed for 1 and 4, the CO stretching frequencies are only slightly shifted (2–3 cm–1) from that expected for free CO (Figure S17), indicating inaccessibility of Fe3+ and Cr3+ and as such very weak van der Waals interactions between the framework and guest species. Previous reports showing the IR spectrum of Fe­(III)–CO and Cr­(III)–CO moieties indicate significant shifting of the stretching vibration, further supporting this conclusion. Given that water molecules fill the coordination sphere of two metals per cluster in the single crystal structure of [Fe3O­(H2O)2(OH)­[(BPDC)3] (1), it is expected that 2/3 of the metals should be accessible per cluster postactivation. This inaccessibility, however, implies that the higher charge density of Fe3+ and Cr3+ inhibits activation at 150 °C, likely due to stronger interaction with the surface appended solvent molecules; however, efforts to activate the samples at higher temperatures approaching 180 °C lead to partial decomposition of the framework before full activation can be achieved.
elements.clean_text: Despite the similarities in the structures of the SBU, there are wide variations in the adsorption properties of the resulting MOFs. The significant differences in the CO2 adsorption behavior might be related to any one or combination of the following: the presence of OMCs that give rise to differences in binding energies, variations in the level of activation and/or accessibility of the OMCs, and the aforementioned defects. Given the higher Q st for 3 and 4, we decided to use in situ DRIFTs to probe the presence of OMCs, which are known to increase binding energy and the surface packing density of adsorbates, provide selectivity for the adsorption of CO2 over N2, and also, on a few occasions, provide a means to achieve charge transfer between the MOF and guest species. For this, MOFs 1-4 were activated at 150 °C and then dosed with CO (5-20 mbar), and in situ DRIFTs data were collected at 150 K. When compared with the stretching mode of free CO (2143 cm-1), 2 and 3 show significant blue-shifts approximately 20 cm-1 (2163 cm-1) and 30 cm-1 (2173 cm-1), respectively, indicating a strong interaction between the CO and the framework (, see detailed discussion in Figure S17). The observed stretching frequencies are consistent with those previously reported for Co2(dobdc) (2164 cm-1) and Ni2(dobdc) (2174 cm-1) with 20 mbar of CO, which are known to have OMCs. This result implies that Co2+ and Ni2+ sites of 2 and 3 are accessible post activation (see the Supporting Information for further details). When the same experiment is performed for 1 and 4, the CO stretching frequencies are only slightly shifted (2-3 cm-1) from that expected for free CO (Figure S17), indicating inaccessibility of Fe3+ and Cr3+ and as such very weak van der Waals interactions between the framework and guest species. Previous reports showing the IR spectrum of Fe(III)-CO and Cr(III)-CO moieties indicate significant shifting of the stretching vibration, further supporting this conclusion. Given that water molecules fill the coordination sphere of two metals per cluster in the single crystal structure of [Fe3O(H2O)2(OH)[(BPDC)3] (1), it is expected that 2/3 of the metals should be accessible per cluster postactivation. This inaccessibility, however, implies that the higher charge density of Fe3+ and Cr3+ inhibits activation at 150 °C, likely due to stronger interaction with the surface appended solvent molecules; however, efforts to activate the samples at higher temperatures approaching 180 °C lead to partial decomposition of the framework before full activation can be achieved.

elements.content: These clusters were additionally used as SBUs for other MOFs with different dicarboxylate ligands. First, H2-BDC acid was used to synthesize a series of MOFs with the MIL-88 structure type. Several MOFs were prepared from the five trimeric clusters including Fe3O (6), Fe2CoO (7), Fe2NiO (8), Fe2CrO (9), and Cr3O (10). The XRD patterns of 6, 7, and 8 are in good agreement with the simulated MIL-88 pattern (); however, XRD patterns of the two Cr-containing materials, 9 and 10, indicate gelation rather than crystallization (Figure S18). Efforts to crystallize the materials under varying reaction conditions were never successful. However, the FT-IR spectra of 6–10 all indicate (i) the disappearance of the stretching modes associated with the acetate ions, (ii) the appearance of new COO- stretching modes of the BDC2– ligand coordinated to the metals (Figure S19), and (iii) the existence of the μ3-oxo stretches associated with the corresponding cluster. These results indicate that the gelatinous materials, 9 and 10, likely contain the same building units as the corresponding MOFs 6–8. As in the case of the BPDC2– ligand, slower exchange rates of Cr3+ likely inhibit crystallization.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of MOFs with Varying Clusters and H2-BDC

These clusters were additionally used as SBUs for other MOFs with different dicarboxylate ligands. First, H2-BDC acid was used to synthesize a series of MOFs with the MIL-88 structure type. Several MOFs were prepared from the five trimeric clusters including Fe3O (6), Fe2CoO (7), Fe2NiO (8), Fe2CrO (9), and Cr3O (10). The XRD patterns of 6, 7, and 8 are in good agreement with the simulated MIL-88 pattern (); however, XRD patterns of the two Cr-containing materials, 9 and 10, indicate gelation rather than crystallization (Figure S18). Efforts to crystallize the materials under varying reaction conditions were never successful. However, the FT-IR spectra of 6-10 all indicate (i) the disappearance of the stretching modes associated with the acetate ions, (ii) the appearance of new COO- stretching modes of the BDC2- ligand coordinated to the metals (Figure S19), and (iii) the existence of the μ3-oxo stretches associated with the corresponding cluster. These results indicate that the gelatinous materials, 9 and 10, likely contain the same building units as the corresponding MOFs 6-8. As in the case of the BPDC2- ligand, slower exchange rates of Cr3+ likely inhibit crystallization.

elements.content: Like MIL-88, MOFs 6, 7, and 8 are flexible frameworks that collapse after activation and hence are nonporous to N2 at 77 K (Figure S22). Framework collapse does not occur in any of the frameworks containing the BPDC2– ligand (1–4), a result of interpenetration allowed by the extended biphenyl ligand that pins the framework open. It should be noted that the gels formed from the Cr-containing clusters and BDC2–, 9 and 10, show significant porosity, indicating the defects associated with the gel formation also inhibit framework collapse as noted by considerable accessible surface areas of 2066 and 581 m2/g, respectively (Figure S23A). The excess CO2 adsorption isotherms of 9 and 10 also show a capacity of 1.79 and 1.21 mmol/g at 298 K and 1 bar (Figure S23B). Additionally, despite their collapse, 6, 7, and 8 show some CO2 adsorption with capacities of 1.29, 0.16, and 0.48 mmol/g at 298 K and 1 bar (Figure S24), respectively. This result indicates that the smaller kinetic diameter of CO2 (3.30 Å) versus N2 (3.64 Å) or the stronger interaction between the framework and CO2 allows accessibility to the pores.

elements.content: It should also be noted that while varying reaction conditions to obtain a crystalline product of 6, with the Fe3(μ3-O) core and the BDC2– ligand, a phase change is observed. The PXRD pattern of the material quenched at different times (Figure S25) shows first the formation of a gelatinous phase, followed by the formation of Bragg reflections at very low angles (below 5°), and then the final crystallization of 6. A close investigation of the PXRD pattern at the intermediate reaction time of 3 h indicates the formation of a material with a significantly larger unit cell, like MIL-101, as indicated by diffraction peaks at low angles. This material quenched in 3 h, although still largely gelatinous, shows a high BET surface area of 1153 m2/g (Figure S26). This is likely indicating that this is a metastable phase that forms in route to MIL-88 and provides evidence that under the proper reaction conditions other structures containing the same building blocks might also be accessible.

elements.content: Last, the five trimeric clusters were used to synthesize MOFs with 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid (H2-BipyDC) as the framework ligand. With the exception of the Cr3O cluster, all reactions yielded a crystalline product. A single crystal taken from the reaction containing the Fe2Co­(μ3-O) core revealed a new crystal structure (CCDC deposition 1539825), 11, showing that the Fe2CoO cluster decomposed during synthesis (Figure S27). This is not surprising as a few previous reports show that amine appendage onto trimeric SBUs in MOFs can sometimes lead to framework decomposition. Further, a previous work of Christou et al., albeit focused on molecular magnetism, shows that the Fe3O core decomposes into an Fe8 wheel cluster upon introduction to triethylamine. Binding of the strong N-containing Lewis base to the metal likely decreases the strength of the M−μ3-oxo bond, decreasing the structural integrity of the cluster. This result implies that these clusters are likely not always suitable to synthesize MOFs with nitrogen-containing ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of MOFs with Varying Clusters and H2-BipyDC

Last, the five trimeric clusters were used to synthesize MOFs with 2,2'-bipyridine-5,5'-dicarboxylic acid (H2-BipyDC) as the framework ligand. With the exception of the Cr3O cluster, all reactions yielded a crystalline product. A single crystal taken from the reaction containing the Fe2Co(μ3-O) core revealed a new crystal structure (CCDC deposition 1539825), 11, showing that the Fe2CoO cluster decomposed during synthesis (Figure S27). This is not surprising as a few previous reports show that amine appendage onto trimeric SBUs in MOFs can sometimes lead to framework decomposition. Further, a previous work of Christou et al., albeit focused on molecular magnetism, shows that the Fe3O core decomposes into an Fe8 wheel cluster upon introduction to triethylamine. Binding of the strong N-containing Lewis base to the metal likely decreases the strength of the M-μ3-oxo bond, decreasing the structural integrity of the cluster. This result implies that these clusters are likely not always suitable to synthesize MOFs with nitrogen-containing ligands.

elements.content: The final product, 11, is a newly reported MOF that also features Fe3+/Co2+ units, albeit the original SBU has undergone a structural rearrangement to form linear, trimeric chains containing 2 × μ2-oxo bridges interlinked by 2,2-bipyridine-5,5-dicarboxylate ligands (see Figure S27). The new MOF, Fe2Co­(μ2-o)2(bipydc)2(H2O)2, crystallizes in a tetragonal unit cell, P43212 (96), and has a BET surface area of 508 m2/g with reasonably good CO2 adsorption properties, 3.10 mmol/g at 1 bar and 298 K (Figure S30), despite some impurities. Compared to the simulated powder pattern, the diffraction patterns of products obtained from the reactions containing other clusters might indicate a similar structure forms (Figures S31 and S32). However, the resulting powder patterns lack the purity and quality necessary to infer anything from a structural analysis. Given the cluster decomposition observed in the Fe2Co analogue, we did not further work to develop the synthetic procedures necessary to obtain pure materials or continue trying to grown single crystals of the other analogues as it is beyond the scope of this work.

elements.content: The obtained results imply that it is indeed possible to use a variety of trimeric metal clusters as predefined SBUs for the formation of isostructural series of MOFs (using non-nitrogenous ligands); however, to the best of our knowledge, no detailed studies have shown that the clusters remain intact during the ligand exchange process for MOF formation. As such, we have used ESI-MS and NMR to monitor ligand exchange processes and XAS to probe quenched reactions for each corresponding MOF to show that the clusters remain in tact throughout the reaction process.
elements.clean_text:
Possible Mechanism for the Formation of MOFs Using Metal Clusters as SBU

The obtained results imply that it is indeed possible to use a variety of trimeric metal clusters as predefined SBUs for the formation of isostructural series of MOFs (using non-nitrogenous ligands); however, to the best of our knowledge, no detailed studies have shown that the clusters remain intact during the ligand exchange process for MOF formation. As such, we have used ESI-MS and NMR to monitor ligand exchange processes and XAS to probe quenched reactions for each corresponding MOF to show that the clusters remain in tact throughout the reaction process.

elements.content: For ESI-MS, the acetate-capped [Fe3O­(CH3CO2)6(H2O)3]+ cluster was soaked in a solution containing benzoic acid as a model reaction, and the mass spectrum was obtained immediately after mixing. The species observed in the reaction are shown in . The two most intense peaks observed at m/z values of 909.97 and 847.96 represent the [Fe­(III)3O­(C6H5CO2)6]+ and [Fe­(III)3O­(C6H5CO2)5­(CH3CO2)]+, respectively. The other two peaks, located at m/z values of 788.94 and 726.93, represent two mixed-valence clusters including [Fe­(III/II)3O­(C6H5CO2)5]+ and [Fe­(III/II)3O­(C6H5CO2)4(CH3CO2)]+. Despite the reduced oxidation state of iron, which is likely induced by the high voltage at the nebulizer used to generate the electrospray, the clusters still show nearly complete ligand exchange (with 5 or 6 acetic acid molecules replaced) in less than 2 min. These results indicate that the ligand exchange process between the capping ligand in the cluster and the added ligand are quite rapid. However, it is possible that these rates are strongly dependent on concentration and pK a of the corresponding ligands. Considering the similarities in the pK a of the benzoic acid and the dicarboxylates used in this study, it is likely that the exchange of the capping ligand can occur very rapidly, and the deprotonation of the second carboxylate is the rate-limiting step in the initial gelation, which we have observed to occur before MOF crystallization. We consider this to be the rate-limiting step as the reaction takes several days at room temperature before the gelation begins to form. It should be noted that ESI-MS experiments with the dicarboxylates failed due to gelation induced at the nebulizer, which then causes the system to plug.

elements.content: Considering that the high energy of the nebulizer in the ESI-MS experiment can potentially influence what is observed, as a second step, NMR data were collected on the same reaction to see if any dynamics related to the ligand exchange process could be extracted. Because of the paramagnetic behavior of iron oxide, 1H NMR was not suitable for structural determination nor for a dynamic study due to the very low spectral resolution. Given this, we moved toward 13C NMR, which has a larger chemical shift domain and also because 13C peaks are less broadened than 1H peaks in the presence of paramagnetic impurities, making it less subject to signal overlap. 13C NMR is known to have a weak sensitivity mainly due to the low natural abundance of 13C (1%), its lower magnetogyric ratio with respect to 1H (1Hγ/13Cγ ≈ 4), and also a general tendency to have longer relaxation delays, especially when speaking of proton isolated carbons such as carbonyl (t 1 ≈ 20–30 s). We compensated the low abundance by using 99% 13C-labeled molecules and took advantage of the presence of paramagnetic species to reduce drastically the recycling delay to one second without observing any significant effect on peak intensity. As shown in A, the Fe3O cluster was synthesized with the carbonyl of the capping acetate labeled with 13C. First, a spectrum of the starting material in DMSO-d 6, which shows a slightly broaden signal at ∼173.5 ppm, was collected (in red). This signal comes from the carbonyl of the previously mentioned 13C-labeled acetate bound to the cluster. After adding benzoic acid into the same NMR tube, a new spectrum was immediately acquired. One intense, sharp peak appears at 172.5 ppm (in green), which is the characteristic peak of the 13C carbonyl now as a free acetic acid molecule. This conclusion is confirmed by comparing the spectrum with those of the pure 13C-labeled acetic acid and 13C-labeled benzoic acid in DMSO-d 6 (in yellow). The obvious peak shift indicates that the acetic acid bound to the Fe3O cluster undergoes full exchange with benzoic acid and is very fast with regard to the NMR time scale. The chemical shift (174 ppm shift to 172 ppm in DMF-d 7) could also be observed when the same 13C-labeled Fe3O cluster was mixed with H2BPDC (B), also confirming an instantaneous exchange with respect to the NMR time scale. Further, considering the MOF crashes out of solution as the second deprotonation process occurs, this data implies that this second step indeed is the rate-limiting one in the MOF formation.

elements.content: After the first ligand exchange, X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was used to probe whether the clusters stay in tact while heated in the reaction mixture. XAS is a powerful tool that reflects the electronic and structural environment for a metal ion in a given sample. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) is particularly good for following the state of the metal cluster during the MOF synthesis. As such, we used this technique to analyze samples from three different stages of the MOF synthesis, including the starting clusters, intermediate gels and/or precipitated species from the mother liquor, and final MOF product for all materials studied, 1–10. The X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) for the Fe3O trimeric cluster, the amorphous intermediate of this cluster with BDC2– or BPDC2–, and the final crystalline products of 1 and 6 are shown in A. Clearly, the position of the Fe K edges and the corresponding shapes are the same for all samples (approximately 7132 eV), indicating similarities in the Fe3+ coordination environment. Also, a similar pre-edge peak is observed for all samples (B), indicating similar coordination geometries for Fe3+. For regular O h symmetry, only electric quadrupole transitions occur, resulting in weak pre-edge peak intensity. However, distortion of the symmetry from O h tends to enhance the pre-edge peak intensity. As shown in B, obvious pre-edge peaks are observed for the clusters and MOFs. This indicates that Fe3+ in the cluster and MOFs are slightly distorted O h , an observation that is corroborated by the crystal structures of the clusters and MOFs. Further, the pre-edge peak is a doublet and could be ascribed to the electric quadrupole transition of the 1s electron to the t2g and eg orbitals. For more detailed structural information about the local Fe environment, the EXAFS data were collected (B), and subsequently the Fourier transformed EXAFS spectra were obtained (C). Next, structural parameters were extracted via curve fitting of the Fourier transformed EXAFS spectra. For this, the Fe3O cluster obtained from a reported crystal structure was used as a reference. Good fits to these spectra were obtained (C) by including atoms of seven paths up to 3.8 Å. The parameters derived from the fits (Table S3) reveal the Fe–O and Fe–Fe distances are consistent with the reference sample. It is worth mentioning that the Fe–Fe distance of these samples is between 3.2 and 3.3 Å. For monomeric units, no such Fe–Fe distance should be observed, and for reported dimeric Fe3+ clusters, the reported Fe–Fe distances are ∼3.4–3.5 Å, which are significantly longer than we have observe here. These refined data clearly give evidence that the M3(μ3-oxo) trimeric cluster were present during different stages of the reaction, likely indicating that there is no decomposition before the MOF formation.

elements.content: Because of the potential difference in cluster stability with metal substitution, we have extended this same experiment to MOFs 1–10. The XANES and EXAFS data of Fe2Ni, Fe2Co, Fe2Cr, and Cr3O at different stages of the MOF synthesis are shown in Figures S30–S33. As in the case of the Fe3O cluster, the XANES and EXAFS data correspond to that of the reference cluster. Good fits to these spectra were obtained, and the structural parameters derived from the fits are provided in Tables S4–S6. The refined EXAFS data demonstrate Fe–Fe (or Cr–Cr) distances for all of these samples, 1–10, are ∼3.3 Å, proving these clusters are well maintained during the MOF formation.

elements.content: Based on the above results, a possible mechanism for the formation of two families of MOFs constructed from predefined M3(μ3-O) SBUs is proposed (). First, the metal cluster (A) is mixed with the dicarboxylate ligand, which rapidly exchanges with the surface capping acetic acid. Next, the second carboxylate undergoes deprotonation to attach to neighboring clusters through a slower exchange process to form larger metal clusters (B), which will continue to exchange with ligands on neighboring clusters until they reaching a critical mass where precipitation of gels occur. With continued heating over time the lability of the ligands in nonkinetically inert clusters allows eventual crystallization (D).

Next, the second carboxylate undergoes deprotonation to attach to neighboring clusters through a slower exchange process to form larger metal clusters (B), which will continue to exchange with ligands on neighboring clusters until they reaching a critical mass where precipitation of gels occur. With continued heating over time the lability of the ligands in nonkinetically inert clusters allows eventual crystallization (D).

elements.content: We have demonstrated the formation of an isostructural series of MOFs by carrying out ligand exchange of a series of five trimeric clusters containing various transitions metals. This effort is proven effective to create materials with the same topology yet varying composition. Thus far, none of the MOFs with mixed metals in the SBUs (2, 3, 4, and 9) are readily accessed in syntheses that employ the individual metal salts. Further, we have demonstrated that adding weaker Lewis acids to the clusters like Ni2+ and Co2+ decreases the strength of surface bound solvent, allowing it to be removed. This gives access to these metals postactivation, enhancing the isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption and making them of interest in a variety of other applications related to catalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have demonstrated the formation of an isostructural series of MOFs by carrying out ligand exchange of a series of five trimeric clusters containing various transitions metals. This effort is proven effective to create materials with the same topology yet varying composition. Thus far, none of the MOFs with mixed metals in the SBUs (2, 3, 4, and  9) are readily accessed in syntheses that employ the individual metal salts. Further, we have demonstrated that adding weaker Lewis acids to the clusters like Ni2+ and Co2+ decreases the strength of surface bound solvent, allowing it to be removed. This gives access to these metals postactivation, enhancing the isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption and making them of interest in a variety of other applications related to catalysis.

elements.content: It appears that the five as-synthesized SBUs remain in tact when using nitrogen-free carboxylic acids as ligands; it is thought that strong Lewis base functionality, as in the case of the BipyDC2– ligand, likely destabilizes the cluster causing their rearrangement into a different trimeric core. Despite this, the rearrangement of the SBU appears to be systematic, this time leading to the formation of new metal-substituted MOFs (Figure S27), whose properties will be further explored.
elements.clean_text: It appears that the five as-synthesized SBUs remain in tact when using nitrogen-free carboxylic acids as ligands; it is thought that strong Lewis base functionality, as in the case of the BipyDC2- ligand, likely destabilizes the cluster causing their rearrangement into a different trimeric core. Despite this, the rearrangement of the SBU appears to be systematic, this time leading to the formation of new metal-substituted MOFs (Figure S27), whose properties will be further explored.

elements.content: This work provides more insight into the controlled construction of MOFs with predefined SBUs. It is hoped that similar methods can be applied to new SBUs, not yet observed in MOF chemistry, or for the creation of more complex materials with mixed metals or multivariate systems containing SBUs with different shapes and connectivity. We have proven the clusters conserve their structural integrity during MOF formation via XAS. We believe trying to understand the stability of other SBUs using these methodologies can provide insight into how to achieve controlled ligand exchange processes, giving experimentalists the possibility to construct a wide range of new MOFs with preconceived functionality.

cln_elements.content:
Nitrogen adsorption measurements of 1–4 show a typical type I isotherm indicative of microporosity (A). The BET surface areas of MOFs synthesized from Fe2NiO (4), Fe2CoO (3), or Fe2CrO (2) are 830, 1327, and 2000 m2/g, respectively. The Fe3O-BPDC analogue (1) has a surface area, 1690 m2/g, similarly reported for MOF-126 by Serre et al. The gelatinous phase containing the Cr3O cluster, 5, exhibits a BET surface area of 602 m2/g (Figure S10). While this surface area was obtained using normal activation procedures with heat and vacuum, it is expected that higher surface areas could be achieved with supercritical CO2 extraction. While it is not known why the surface areas of 2 and 3 are so much lower than 1 and 4, it could be related to crystalline defects induced by the mismatch in the ligand exchange rate of the M2+ and M3+ cations in 2 and 3, differences in nucleation and growth rates, or other issues regarding the framework charge. For 1 and 4, the clusters are charged, while those in 2 and 3 are neutral, which could lend to differences in charge balancing guests and solvent located in the channels.

Given the considerable surface area of this isostructural series and the propensity of the M3(μ3-O) core to form open metal coordination sites (OMCs) upon activation, the CO2 adsorption properties of these MOFs were probed at 298 K. B and Figure S14 show the room-temperature excess adsorption isotherms for 1–5. Surprisingly, these MOFs showed moderate to excellent CO2 adsorption capacities. Especially 1, synthesized from Fe3O cluster, reached 4.04 mmol of CO2 per gram at atmospheric pressure. For 2, 3, 4, and 5, the capacities are 2.00, 1.78, 1.02 (B), and 1.01 mmol/g (Figure S14) at atmospheric pressure. Additionally, isosteric heats were extracted from the variable temperature CO2 adsorption isotherms ranging from 288 to 308 K. The CO2 adsorption isotherms collected at 288, 298, and 308 K were fitted with a dual-site Langmuir model (Table S2 and Figure S15), and then the Clausius–Clapeyron equation was subsequently used to extract the isosteric heats of CO2 adsorption, Q st. The Q st are plotted as a function of CO2 loading in Figure S16. At zero coverage the values are 20.5, 23.7, 27.4, and 20.8 kJ mol–1 for 1, 2, 3, and 4, respectively. It should be noted that despite their lower overall CO2 capacity and surface area, analogues that contain neutral clusters (Fe2CoO-BPDC (2) and Fe2NiO-BPDC (3)) have a higher Q st, with Ni2+ showing the highest of 27.4 kJ/mol. These significant differences in the corresponding isosteric heats likely imply that the identity of the metal significantly influences the strength of binding.

It should also be noted that while varying reaction conditions to obtain a crystalline product of 6, with the Fe3(μ3-O) core and the BDC2– ligand, a phase change is observed. The PXRD pattern of the material quenched at different times (Figure S25) shows first the formation of a gelatinous phase, followed by the formation of Bragg reflections at very low angles (below 5°), and then the final crystallization of 6. A close investigation of the PXRD pattern at the intermediate reaction time of 3 h indicates the formation of a material with a significantly larger unit cell, like MIL-101, as indicated by diffraction peaks at low angles. This material quenched in 3 h, although still largely gelatinous, shows a high BET surface area of 1153 m2/g (Figure S26). This is likely indicating that this is a metastable phase that forms in route to MIL-88 and provides evidence that under the proper reaction conditions other structures containing the same building blocks might also be accessible.

The final product, 11, is a newly reported MOF that also features Fe3+/Co2+ units, albeit the original SBU has undergone a structural rearrangement to form linear, trimeric chains containing 2 × μ2-oxo bridges interlinked by 2,2-bipyridine-5,5-dicarboxylate ligands (see Figure S27). The new MOF, Fe2Co­(μ2-o)2(bipydc)2(H2O)2, crystallizes in a tetragonal unit cell, P43212 (96), and has a BET surface area of 508 m2/g with reasonably good CO2 adsorption properties, 3.10 mmol/g at 1 bar and 298 K (Figure S30), despite some impurities. Compared to the simulated powder pattern, the diffraction patterns of products obtained from the reactions containing other clusters might indicate a similar structure forms (Figures S31 and S32). However, the resulting powder patterns lack the purity and quality necessary to infer anything from a structural analysis. Given the cluster decomposition observed in the Fe2Co analogue, we did not further work to develop the synthetic procedures necessary to obtain pure materials or continue trying to grown single crystals of the other analogues as it is beyond the scope of this work.
